title: Incomplete submersion pool volume
vignette: The town pool holds only thirty-eight units of rainwater, shy of the required forty.

options.text: Add collected rainwater until it reaches forty units before use.
Use it anyway since it's close to the minimum.

title: Mixing drawn water first
vignette: Workers accidentally pour three buckets of tap water into the empty pit before any rain falls.

options.text: Disqualify it; drawn water must not precede the rain.
Add plenty of rainwater later and use it.

title: Pipe-fed submersion pool
vignette: A new bath uses pipes to bring rainwater directly from the roof.

options.text: Piped water is acceptable if not drawn by vessels.
Only naturally gathered water counts; pipes invalidate.

title: Painted walls flaking
vignette: Paint chips fall into the submersion pool as people immerse.

options.text: The flakes are negligible; continue using it.
Stop use until the paint is removed and water replaced.

title: Standing vs flowing water
vignette: A spring feeds the submersion pool but the water becomes stagnant during the summer.

options.text: As long as it's spring water, submersion is valid.
It must be flowing at submersion time to count.

title: Cracked basin leaking
vignette: Small cracks cause the submersion pool to slowly leak below forty units overnight.

options.text: Repair it and refill before the next use.
Use while water remains, even if below measure later.

title: Submersion of utensils
vignette: Merchants dip new metal cups in the submersion pool one after another without drying them first.

options.text: Utensils may be immersed even consecutively without issue.
Moisture from each contaminates the next; dry them first.

title: Using melted snow
vignette: Snow is gathered and melted to top off the submersion pool during a drought.

options.text: Melted snow counts as natural water and is fine.
Only direct rainfall is acceptable; reject the snowmelt.

title: Heated water added
vignette: They warm some rainwater before pouring it into the cold submersion pool.

options.text: Heating does not disqualify; mix it in.
Once heated, it's drawn water and invalid.

title: Portable submersion tub
vignette: A traveler fills a large barrel with rainwater to use as a personal submersion pool on the road.

options.text: A movable container cannot serve as a valid submersion pool.
If it holds forty units, it works wherever it sits.

title: Submersion pool built by untrained crew
vignette: Local workers lacking specialized cleanliness training dig and plaster the new facility.

options.text: Construction by anyone is fine if guidelines are met.
Only a specially trained crew ensures reliability.

title: Doubtful measurement
vignette: After renovations, nobody recalls whether the submersion pool was measured accurately.

options.text: Re-measure to ensure forty units before further use.
Assume it remains valid based on past use.

title: Corpse falls into the submersion pool
vignette: A small animal dies and is found floating in the water.

options.text: Discard the water and decontaminate the basin before reuse.
Scoop out the carcass and continue using the water.

title: Shared clothing at submersion
vignette: People borrow communal robes to wear when dipping because they own none.

options.text: Borrowed garments are fine if they are clean.
Each person must own personal clothing for the procedure.

title: Submersion at twilight
vignette: Someone finishes submersion just as the sun sets, leaving doubt whether it was day or night.

options.text: It counts for that day since part was before sunset.
Repeat at clear daylight to avoid any question.
